ABSTRACT

ALVES, Marcelo Ferreira de Souza. AnÃ¡lise crÃ­tica dos valores de propriedades acÃºsticas e cÃ¡lculos derivados: dispersÃ£o de dados na literatura e investigaÃ§Ã£o de causas . Rio de Janeiro, 2021. DissertaÃ§Ã£o (Mestrado em Engenharia de Processos QuÃ­micos e BioquÃ­micos) - Escola de QuÃ­mica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, 2021.

Analytical characterization of fluids by ultrasound was investigated in a literature review. We searched the literature for ultrasonic speed in water and n -decane and found small variabilities reported, most lower than 1.6 m/s for the studied data, 1559 data points for water and 129 for n -decane. We conducted a statistical compatibility analysis on data under statistically similar experimental conditions, both by considering confidence interval superposition. Resulting in no change in conclusions, we ran the analysis for different confidence levels to create the confidence intervals that, justified by literatur e, only considered pressure and temperature to distinguish experimental conditions. The study showed that, despite small variabilities, much of the speeds in statistically similar experimental conditions were not statistically compatible (differences over 40 m/s were observed) . The lack of consensus and possible lack of multiple data for a same experimental condition highlight the difficulty in searching for values of reference. Seeking an explanation, multiple sources of variability were investigated. Amon g them, a gap in data processing was identified; several can be used and yield in different results, although many times they are not even mentioned. By means of an experimental investigation, their impact was shown to be possible of explaining the observe d differences in literature. Data from water and n -decane obtained in a pulse -echo cell were processed. Eighteen processing techniques were applied, including threshold techniques, cross correlation and Hilbert transform, and fluctuations of up to more than 82 m/s were observed. Their impact, though, was shown dependent of the experimental arrangement. The processing for calculation of density and attenuation by acoustic method was also studied.
Keywords: Acoustic spectros copy, Ultrasound, Data processing, Time of flight , Literature evaluation.

Ultrasonics Critical evaluation of ultrasound propagation speeds: dispersion of data and sources of variability Marcelo Ferreira de Souza Alvesa,*, FÃ¡bio Pedro do Nascimentoa, Renato Malbar Musiello Barcellosa, Eduardo Mach Queiroza, Marco Antonio Gomes Teixeirab, Ana Mehla a: Escola de QuÃ­mica. Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Cidade UniversitÃ¡ria, 21941 -909 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil.
b: Instituto de QuÃ­mica/GQA. Universidade Federal Fluminense, Centro de Estudos Gerais, 24020 -150 - NiterÃ³i, RJ, Brazil.

* marcelo.alv es.ufrj@gmail.com Abstract We searched the literature for data on ultrasonic speed in water and n -decane and found small variabilities reported, most lower than 1.6 m/s for the studied data. We conducted a statistical compatibility analysis (similar study was not found) on data under s tatistically similar experimental conditions. We ran the analysis for different confidence levels with confidence intervals that, justified by literature, only considered pressure and temperature to distinguish experimental conditions. The study showed tha t, despite small variabilities, much of the speeds in statistically similar experimental conditions were not statistically compatible. The lack of consensus and possible lack of multiple data for a same experimental condition highlight the difficulty in se arching for references. Seeking an explanation, a gap in data processing was identified; several can be used and yield in different results. By means of an experimental investigation, their impact was shown to be possible of explaining the differences in l iterature. Data obtained in a pulse -echo cell were processed. Eighteen processing techniques were applied, including threshold techniques, cross correlation and Hilbert transform, and fluctuations of up to more than 82 m/s were observed. Their impact, thou gh, was shown dependent of the experimental arrangement.
Keywords: Acoustic spectroscopy, Ultrasound, Data processing, Time of flight, Literature evaluation.
1. Introduction

Ultrasound is a periodic mechanical wave defined when its frequency is between 20 kHz and 500 MHz, for condensed phases [1]. The vibration caused molecules can be longitudinal (oscillation in the direction of the waveÂ´s movement) in all media, but only in solids in transversal (oscillation perpendicular to waveÂ´s movement) pr opagated; in both cases, there are cycles on compression and rarefaction [1].

Besides frequency, amplitude and phase are used to fully characterized the wave. The former can be measured by the power or intensity of the wave [2] while the latter refers to t he regions of the wave, for example, points of maximum and minimum pressure generated [3].

Those three parameters of the wave can be explored in different uses of ultrasound, but it`s frequency and amplitude that define the two main classes of use as they, combined, are determinants to the effect the medium is going to experience. Frequency determines how long particles stay in the temporary new positions caused by the wave while the amplitude determines how far the new position is from the resting position . The first class of use discussed is power ultrasound, one that aims for permanent changes in the medium. It combines low frequencies (usually 20 to 100 kHz), thus resulting in particles spending longer times in the new positions, with high amplitudes (us ually intensities from 10 to 1000 ğ‘Š/ğ‘š2), resulting in particles far from each other in the rarefaction part of the wave cycle. On the other hand, the analytical use applies higher frequencies (usually in the order of MHz), causing molecules to stay apart only for shorter periods, which makes the intensity needed for permanent changes remarkably high26. Even so, low intensities are used, making it possible to obtain useful information from the Among the interfering uses are cleaning baths and reaction catalysis while analytical uses include medical diagnostical tests [1] and fluid characterization [3].

26 For example, cavitation in water at 1 MHz would require 240 times the intensity needed at 10 kHz (650 In this work, analytical use for fluid characterization is of interest as it is part of a research project funded by a private oil and gas company to study composition and properties determination on emulsions and monophase fluids by ultrasound. Then, particularly of interest is acoustic spectroscopy, an analytical technique based on the analysis of ultrasound going through a sample for prope rties calculation [6] based on theoretical reasoning on the experimental system [7,8]. Among the benefits of acoustic spectroscopy are safety, not needed dilution, possibility of use in non -transparent media, being fast, reliable, and nondestructive [18].

Frequencies between 0.1 MHz and 100 MHz are the commonly applied [9] and the properties of interest are measured through the determination of acoustic properties of the sample. The most used ones are the ultrasound attenuation and ultrasound speed [10, 11 ], which at the frequency range applied, equals the speed of sound on the medium [12], that is a thermodynamic property and, thus, can be used for thermophysical properties calculation [13].

The speed is the ratio of a distance traveled per the taken time27 [14] while attenuation is a measure of the energy lost per distance traveled [9]. Both the speed [15] and attenuation [16, 17] are quantities dependent on the sample analyzed and thatÂ´s why they can be used in fluid characterization. Regarding speed, it is also important to clarify that one might read about phase speed or group speed. Both have, basically, the same meaning but phase speed is said when it refers to a monofrequency signal and group speed when referring to a multifrequency one, that is, a pu lse [3]. Although the definitions of the properties are well set, property calculation, experimental measurement process and the sharing of data in the literature are not unique. There are multiply causes of variability possible.
Regarding the sharing of data, values can be shown in tables, in graphs or equations. When one wants to use them, the number can be clear in tables, but reading

27 Alternatively, th e speed can be d escribed as function of periodic wave parameters as being the ratio between wavelength and wave period or the product of wav elength and frequency [14]. If more than one single frequency is present in the signal though, itÂ´s imperative to as sess them individually if one wants to use wave parameters for speed calculation [19].

graphs can introduce variability as people may read them slightly different, when data labels are not present. Equations , on the other hand, are somewhat like tables since, given a exact calculation method, result in a unique number for given condition. However, equations come with a lack of fit that can only be estimated when the given experimental condition was not experi mentally measured. Therefore, even same data can be shared and then, interpreted in different ways, introducing variability.

Regarding calculation, acoustic measurement can be made absolute or relative. In the former, no external reference is needed, thus, resulting in some independence to the measurement. This can be done either with other techniques being used for determination of needed parameters (for example, the distance to be traveled by the wave [20]) or with internal references, that is, comparing two signals obtained in the same experiment (for example, comparing different echoes after emitting a pulse [21]). On the other hand, when a relative measurement is carried, an external reference is needed. The measurement process can express the quantity measured as a function of the reference [11] or systematically deduct the effect caused by the reference in the measurements [7]. Although both absolute and relative measurements can be used and great applications studied, one can find in the literature st udies that are not clear about the actual value attributed to reference28 and this can be a problem to researchers looking for reference for their studies. How would one scale a value not know? And how would it be applied to a different system if the refer ence contains more than one effect and they havenÂ´t been isolated29? So, what is being said is that acoustic technology can applied in different ways and, even if affective in all, some results cannot be used by others due to how the measurement or data pr ocessing was done.

Among the experimental variabilities, it can be cited the ultrasound acquisition technique (pulse echo, time of flight, interferometryâ€¦) and the acquisition process configurations (pulse repetition rate, excitation time, gain, filters, damping, sampling rate
28 This doesnÂ´t mean there i s a problem with the study. Being the measurement a relative one, knowing the exact value would matter much for the work done.

29 This remark e specially stands when s olid components are present in the experimental system as microstructure, influenced not only by fabrication but usage, affects its acoustic properties [22, 23]. Therefore, even if the solid material is known, its properties might di ffer from previous calculated ones in similar experimental conditions. Interactions between solid and fluid must also be characterized [24]. â€¦), the experimental system components (number of transducers and their specification, presence of matching layers, presence of delay lines â€¦) and, when a relative measurement is carried, the reference used (meaning both the substanc e at a determined experimental condition and the actual value used for its acoustic property of interest). Furthermore, even in two thought cases where every aforementioned causes of variability were constant, there could still be seen differences in results due to data processing [25]. Analyzing this effect can be complex since even though there is no consensus in a processing technique [26], the one used is often not well explained [27]. With all this background and authors seeming to focus mainly on the experimental process, our research group wanted to know whether our experimental ultrasonic measurements well satisfactory or not. Aiming fluid characterization, focused on emulsions, we need both accuracy and precision. However, when w e first looked for comparison in literature, we found both a reference that agreed with our measurement and a reference that didnÂ´t, both with low uncertainty reported and whose confidence intervals, for our analysis, didnÂ´t agree. So, how to proceed? Was our measurement good since there was one agreement or since there was disagreement? Could the problem be experimental? Could it not?

Then this, now presented, work was idealized. First, we aimed the understanding of how much difference there is in literatu re for ultrasound speed at a given condition, the acoustic parameter of main interest to the research group at the time. Data were systematically collected and analyzed for water, a usual reference in measurements [27, 28, 29], and n -decane, alkane used as surrogate to kerosene [30, 31], both physically available to the group. The data collection yielded 1559 data points available for water and 129 for n -decane. Analysis showed that even though most data, both for water and n-decane, had variabilities less than 1.6 m/s reported30, more than half of the statistically undistinguishable31 experimental conditions had at least one pair of velocities not

30 Several points are reported with even lower variabilities. See, for example, Bollengier, Brown and Shaw (2019) [3 3], who report uncertainties better than 0.5 m/s, Del Grosso (1970) [34], who reports precision better than 0.01 m/s, and Nascimento et al. (2015) [35] who report uncertainties of 0.5 m/s. 31 Two values were considered statistically undistinguishable if the ir confidence intervals were superposed [32] and a experimental condition took into account, beyond composition [15], only temperature a nd pressure of the measurement.

statistically corresponding to the same criteria. The percentage of statistically compatible velocity pair wer e similar, thus revealing that the problem of finding velocities both in agreement and disagreement is common in the literature, that is, the absence of consensus in a value for velocities in a given condition in common. The differences observed were in ge neral comparable to the variabilities of the data acquired in literature. When considering both the statistically undistinguishable and not velocities pairs, the highest median of differences calculated was 0.387 m/s for water and 1.6 m/s for n - decane. How ever, some pairs had whopping differences of more than 10 m/s. For water, there was even one pair of velocities in the same experimental condition that differed in After the lack of consensus was stated, we investigated if the processing techniqu e used to calculate the velocity could explain the differences observed in literature. Eighteen methods were employed to process data acquired in a pulse -echo system, described in Carvalho (2013) [6]. We used both a 2.25 MHz nominal frequency transducer an d a 5.00 MHz to analyze both water and n -decane, the same samples searched in literature. This study showed that processing alone, in this experimental arrangement, could yield more than 70 m/s of difference between results. However, we discuss that the im pact of process might depend on the acquisition system used. Nevertheless, it became clear that processing has to be accounted for if one wants good and comparable results.
2. Materials and Methods
2.1 Literature evaluation

The search for data in the lite rature was done in â€˜PeriÃ³dicos Capesâ€™ (https://www.periodicos.capes.gov.br/), a scientific research tool provided by BrazilÂ´s Ministry of Education and Science. Both for water and n -decane, two searches were performed, each with two expressions. For water, the terms searched were â€œdistilled water speed of soundâ€ or â€œpure water ultrasound speedâ€ and â€œdistilled water sound velocityâ€ or â€œpure water ultrasound velocityâ€. For n -decane, â€œn -decane speed of soundâ€ or â€œn -decane ultrasound speedâ€ and â€œn -decane veloci ty of soundâ€ or â€œn -decane ultrasound velocityâ€. The 30 first results of each search were considered. If any word of the searched terms in the corresponding search were present on the resultÂ´s title, the paper was read. If experimental measurement for ultra sound velocity/speed was obtained by acoustic technique, the data reported was selected for analysis to be included in a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet created. However, since results calculated from equations have an uncertain lack of fit in interpolations, only data expressed as final numbers or in graphs were considered. For the latter, a analysis of the reading of data was performed for each graph. The data were always read using â€˜Pega Pontoâ€™ [36], a software in which one can import the graph of interest, manually set where each axis starts and finishes in the graph and set each as linear or logarithmical, and then, manually click over each point in the graph. Since points in a graph actually have two dimensions and the acquisition process is manual, there is a variability associated with it. This was assessed by choosing one of the points in each graph and repeating all the acquisition process 5 times. The standard deviation of the 5 values was used to represent the variability of given process and associat ed32 to the variability originally reported for the experimental measurement. The data for ultrasound speed selected, along with the reference for the work reporting it, was finally included in the spreadsheet if both temperature and pressure associated w ith the measurement were reported (and then, also included). Additionally, if available, it was included the acquisition technique used, number of replicas, type of data (extracted from a graph or directly reported as a number), the best form of variabilit y present33 for speed, temperature, and pressure and, if the data came from a graph, uncertainties associated with speed, temperature, and pressure.

The spreadsheets for both water and n -decane were then read by a Python code, also by us created, and analy sis were performed after converting all units34. Groups of data in similar (reproducibility) experimental conditions were identified. Considering
32 Graphical and originally reported variabilities were associated by square rooting the ir quadra tic sum if there was a reported variability.

33 Following the definitions and recommendations presented in â€˜Guide to the expression of uncertainty in measurementâ€™ (GUM) [37] and noting that, even with different meanings, there was no unique way to report variabilities in the literature searched, only one form of variability per property was included in the spreadsheet and, if more than one was available, the decreasing order of priority was: standard uncertainty (which is the same as standard dev iation), uncertainty, error or accuracy and resolution or precision. The term used was also added to the spreadsheet. For more details on the definitions for each term, please consult GUM [37].
34 Temperatures were converted to Kelvin, pressure to atmosphe res and speed to meters per second. Variabilities associated were also converted to these units.

temperature and pressure, both identical and compatible conditions were grouped. In the former, both temperature and pressure had to be equal for data, as read by Python after units conversion, to be grouped and, in the latter, the confidence intervals for both variables had to overlap, thus, making them statistically undistinguishable [38]. For the compa tible conditions, sampling with replacement was used and each point was considered a potential generator of a compatible conditions group for its experimental condition. That is, one data point can be present in more than on compatible conditions group.

In the cases where either temperature or pressure (or both) did not have variabilities reported, we performed a type B evaluation of uncertainty considering the ones reported for similar conditions, individually. We did this by dividing the temperature range present in the spreadsheet in 25 equally spaced intervals. For each interval, simple mean was calculated and associated with the mean temperature of the interval35. Whenever the variability associated with a data pointâ€™s temperature wasnÂ´t available, the temperatureâ€™s mean variability associated with the immediately higher mean temperature than the data pointâ€™s was attributed to it, allowing further constructions of compatible conditions blocks. For pressure, a similar procedure was done, but for pressures lower than 10 atm, another 25 divisions were made since not doing this would result in unreasonably high uncertainties for lower pressures due to systematically higher variabilities observed as pressures increased. For example, it would not be reasonable to associated 0.5 atm or 1.0 atm as the variability of a measurement performed in ambient conditions.

The differences in speeds of ultrasound reported for every point in every grouped experimental condition (identical and compatible) were then assessed by comparing the speeds with each other in pairs for all combinations possible. Aside from calculating the numerical differences for each pair, the confidence intervals of the speeds in the pair were taken into account to, similarly than with the temperature s and pressures, classify the pair as statistically undistinguishable (called here a compatible pair) if they overlap or statistically different (called here an incompatible pair), if they donâ€™t. However, for speeds,

35 If there was no data f or a given interval, it was simply ignored, not affecting others. type B uncertainty evaluation was not p erformed, thus, creating a third possibility: incomparable pair, if one of the speeds in the pair does not have a variability associated. So, all speeds assessed in this evaluation were obtained in statistically undistinguishable experimental conditions. If the pair is classified as compatible, it means that the speeds are also statistically undistinguishable. If incompatible, although the experimental conditions were statistically undistinguishable, the speeds are not, which surely would be a problem to t he researcher looking for references. If the pair is incomparable, the pair cannot even be judged.

The analysis of literature is then concluded by checking for evidence of whether the acoustic acquisition technique can be said to influence or not the subgr oups of compatible and incompatible pairs of speeds. We did that by performing hypothesis tests [55] on the relative proportions of pairs of techniques associated with pairs of speed both on the group of statistically undistinguishable experimental conditi ons and the subgroup of compatible or incompatible speeds pairs.

All the analysis were repeated for three different confidence significances but, they were constructed not based on a specific confidence, but varying the multiple of the variability on the c onfidence interval directly. One, two and three were used and the direct changing of them was done so we did not have to assume a probability distribution for the variables. Only on the hypothesis test did we have to assume one for the proportions, which w as Normal.
2.2 Data processing for group speed calculation

To study the impact of the technique used for ultrasound speed calculation, we performed 4 measurements in a pulse -echo system previously used and described by Carvalho (2013) [6], but also here b riefly discussed. Showed in Figure 1, the setup is composed of pulser and receiver ( Olympus 5072PR), an oscilloscope (Tektronix DPO 3032) used to view and then save data, discrete in both axes, to a flash drive and the ultrasonic cell. The measurements wer e made at atmospheric pressure, but o ne should note that temperature was not controlled, although estimated between 20 e 30Â°âˆ, based on room temperature. However, there was no impact on the desired study since only comparations between different data proce ssing on the same data was aimed.
Figure 1. Experimental setup for acoustic data acquisition. 1, Olympus 5072PR Pulser/Receiver; 2, Tektronix DPO 3032 Oscilloscope; 3, Ultrasonic cell.

The pulser was configured to a pulse repetition rate of 1 kHz, energy set to 2 and damping set to 3 (equivalent to 50 Î©). The receptor was set to a 1 MHz high band passing filter and 10 MHz low band passing filter. Its gain was adjusted between 13 and 19 d B, varying for each experiment so to maximize the signal seen on the oscilloscopeâ€™s screen. We set the oscilloscope to acquire data based on a 512 average, so that we could lower noise, and with a 100 MHz sampling frequency, which was more than enough to f ollow Nyquist criteria given our signals. Both vertical and horizontal scales were constant at 20 ğ‘šğ‘‰ and 10 ğœ‡ğ‘  respectively.

The ultrasonic pulse -echo cell, detailed in Figure 2, consists of a double element transducer, made from two delay lines (40.0 millimeters long buffer rod 1 made of rexolite and 46.7 millimeters long buffer rod 2 made of boron silicate glass), a 52 ğœ‡ğ‘š wide gold covered PVDF receiver and a changeable emitter, coupled with a stainless -steel reflector. Between them, a 3.35 millime ters gap holds the sample. Olympusâ€™ transducers of 2.25 MHz and 5.00 MHz nominal frequencies were used as emitters. The samples tested were type 1 ultrapure water (Milli-Q) prepared in a Gehakaâ€™s Master System MS2000 and n - decane supplied by Vetec QuÃ­mica Fina with mass purity higher than 0.99. Both were degassed at 40Â°C for 30 minutes in a ultrasonic bath Q3.0L from Eco -sonics.
Figure 2. Diagram showing construction and highlighting the acoustic model for pulses of interest of the ultrasonic cell used. Adapted from Adamowski et al. (1995) [21].

During the experiments, we adjusted gain in situ to maximize the signal on the screen. For water, gains 13 dB and 16 dB were used with the 2.25 MHz and 5.00 MHz transducers respectively. For n -decane, 14 dB and 19 dB. The acoustic model36 for the cell is also illustrated in Figure 2. It includes the emitted pulse ( ğ‘ğ‘¡) that is detected before coming into contact with the sample, and three The presented cell can be used to calculate speed of ultrasound, density and ultrasound attenuation and has a big enough diameter of receiver so that one could ignore diffractions effects up to 10 MHz as it acts as a plane wave filter [21]. This automated delimitation makes the processing faster and fully objective since we do not interfere after the code was written. Regarding time -of-flight calculation, three subgroups of methods can be highlighted: 1 to 6, 7 to 14 and 15 to 18. Methods 1 to 6 are level measurements; they consider either a threshold or a global maximum of the signal as a time reference to it and, by comparing the references of different signal, time of flight is calculated. Method 1 considered an empirical threshold of 0 .003 V to determine the beginning and ending of pulses. Methods 2 and 3 used the maximum amplitudes of the signals as references, but method 2 considered the signals as measured while, in method, the second pulse was inverted to compensate experimental pha se inversion. Method 4 also relies on a signal maximum but considering its envelope. A signalâ€™s envelope is obtained by finding the absolute value of the analytical signal, defined as a complex value whose real part is the measured signal and imaginary par t is the Hilbert transform of the measured signal, operation defined in Equation 1 [53]. In it, ğ‘ (ğ‘¡) represents the signal to be transformed and ğ‘ â„ğ‘–ğ‘™(ğ‘¡) the result, in the same time domain.

Methods 5 and 6 use the first zero crossing of pulses as a time reference for their start. Both consider signal ğ‘0 and inverted ğ‘1, but, in method 6, the zero -crossing search is refined by a linear interpolation.

Methods 7 to 14 rely on cross correlation. Sometimes called the â€˜classical methodâ€™, the cross -correlationâ€™s basis for determining the time of flight is finding the correlation between two signals for different temporal lags applied to one of them; the lag that yi elds a maximum correlation is taken to be the time of flight [26, 41, 42]. Equation 2 shows the discrete cross correlation, the one applied to signals that are discrete [26]. In Equation 2, ğ‘‡ğ‘ represents the sampling interval and then, (ğ‘âˆ’1)âˆ—ğ‘‡ğ‘ representes the signal window considered.

Method 7 applies the correlation directly on signals measured, while methods 8, 9 and 10 interpolate this result in search for the C.C. maxim um, thus applying a time correction ( Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘› ) on the determined by the C.C.â€™s maximum ( Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’ ), as in Equation 3 [48], getting to a final result to be considered ( Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘™). Method 9 uses Hilbert transform to the entire result, so the C.C. maximumâ€™s search is turned into the transformâ€™s zero crossing search, which is reported to be less subject to error [43]. Method 9 uses parabolic interpolation in the vicinity of the discre te maximum of C.C. (the maximum and the two surrounding points), which is described in Equation 4 [48]. Method 10 considers the same vicinity as method 9, but using cosine interpolation, described in Equation 5, whose parameter ğœ† is described in Equation 6 [27, 44].
In Equations 4, 5, and 6 ğ‘¦0 represent the maximum value of the C.C. , ğ‘¦âˆ’1 represent the value of the C.C. for the immediately lower time lag investigated and ğ‘¦+1, for the immediately higher.

Methods 11 to 14 are similar to methods 7 to 10, but method 11 considered the envelope of the measured signals in the C.C., istead of dir ectly the measured signals, as method 7. Then, method 12 applies cosine interpolation, 13 applies parabolic interpolation and 14 applies the Hilbert transform interpolation. In contrast with the other described methods, methods 11 to 14 were not found des cribed or applied in studies of acoustic spectrocopy. They were inspired in works of sismology [45, 46] were the application of C.C. on the envelopes rather than the directly measured signals is said to more robust since the C.C. would be less susceptable to changes in waveform as envelopes smoothen its inputs (and, for that, could even be downsampled to reduce computacional need) [54].

Table 9 shows whopping differences of up to more than 80 m/s when varying the method of calculation of the time of flight between signals. This value is even greater than the already whopping differences observed in the literatureâ€™s analysis, that surpassed â€˜onlyâ€™ 40 m/s. Both values became even more shocking when put into perspective with th e reported variabilities observed in the literature, whose majority lies below 1.6 m/s. However, we also started a mathematical study to understand if the calculated fluctuation on speeds depended on the experimental arrangement used. For that, we consider ed the greatest fluctuation observed in times of flight, which was e 0.280 ğœ‡ğ‘ , seen for the experiment in n -decane under 5.00 MHz nominal transducer. We calculated how big the error in speed calculation could be if the time of flight was either underesti mated by 0.280 ğœ‡ğ‘  or overestimated by 0.280 ğœ‡ğ‘ , both considered different â€œtrueâ€ values for the speed (which yield in â€œtrueâ€ times of flight) and different acoustic paths. We did the calculations for â€œtrueâ€ speeds of 1000, 2000, 3000, 4000 and 5000 m/s and acoustic paths of 5, 50 and 500 millimeters. For contextualization, in the ambient conditions experiments previously discussed, the ultrasound speed for water was around 1500 m/s and, for n - decane, around 1200 m/s. Ultrasound speeds over 5000 m/s, for example, are observed in solids38. Regarding the acoustic path, the ultrasound cell we used in the previously discussed experiments had a 6.7 millimeters path.
In Figure15, we show the calculations for the maximum underestimates and, in Figure 16, the maximum overestimates, both when applying a 0.280 ğœ‡ğ‘  error to the correct time of flight.
Figure 15. Heatmap showing, in m/s, the maximum underestimates in ultra sound speeds simulated for an overestimation of 0.280 ğœ‡ğ‘  in the time of flight.
38 Doghmane and Hadjoub (1997) [57], for example, report the longitudinal u ltrasound speed for stainless steel as 5840 m/s.
Figure 16. Heatmap showing, in m/s, the maximum overestimates in ultrasound speeds simulated for an underestimation of 0.280 ğœ‡ğ‘  in the time of flight.

Figures 15 and 16 show the impact that a given fluctuation in time of flight measurement could have o n speed calculation in different experimental arrangements. It becomes clear that as experimental apparatus relies on smaller acoustic paths or analyze a sample in which the speed of sound is faster, the fluctuation in speed calculation tends to be greater . However, this study does not answer if the fluctuation in these different experimental arrangements would be similar to that observed in ours. A series of controlled experiments or computational simulations would be needed.
4. Discussion and Conclusions

In this article, we discussed the presence of multiple sources of variability sources in acoustic spectroscopy, highlighting a gap in the often -neglected data processing [27]. We then studied if, even with all the variability sources, the values reported for ultrasound speed statistically agreed with each other for statistically equal experimental conditions, distinguished by temperature and pressure and checked by means of superposition of confidence intervals for three different confidence levels. For th e study, an evaluation of data in literature was conducted. 1559 data for water, from 14 articles, and 129 data for n-decane, from 12 articles, were studied and revealed that most of the experimental conditions with multiple data reported had at least one pair of statistically different speeds. Besides that, it was also observed that most also had at least one pair of statistically similar speeds, shedding light on the possibility of selective comparisons, that is, this result indicated that, given a value of measured speed, one could find either corroborating or conflicting data in literature. Therefore, we suggest the reader to, besides multiple experimental data, also search for largely accepted reference values for the ultrasound speeds. For water, we su ggest the empiric equation present in Del Grosso and Mader (1972) [59], valid in the temperature range from 0,001Â° ğ¶ to 95,126 Â°ğ¶, but limited to atmospheric pressures, and the empiric equation presented in Wilson (1959) [58], valid from temperatures from 0,91â„ƒ to 91,27â„ƒ and pressures from the atmospheric up to around 952 ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘š (14000 psia). For n -decane, we suggest the thermodynamic -based equation presented in Dashti and Riazi (2014) [13], valid in the temperature range from âˆ’73,15â„ƒ to 126 ,85â„ƒ and pressures from atmospheric to around 1480 atm. The differences between both agreeing and contradicting speeds were calculated. Although most differences were small, evidenced by most medians of differences lower than 2 m/s or even 1 m/s, higher differ ences of up to more than 40 m/s were observed. The latter becomes dazzling when put into perspective with reported variabilities for the data, majorly lower than 1.6 m/s.

Finally, we conducted experiments, also in water and n -decane, to understand if the d ata processing alone could yield differences as high as the observed in the literatureâ€™s study of speeds. We used a pulse -echo cell with 6.7 millimeters acoustic path and applying emitters of 2.25 and 5.00 MHz nominal frequencies. Employing eighteen method s for time -of-flight determination, we observed fluctuations over 67 m/s for the experiments in n -decane and over 82 m/s for water. Those values, clearly greater than the 1.6 m/s below which relied most reported variabilities, are even greater than the maximum variabilities reported (around 25 m/s for n -decane and around 16 m/s for water). However, even though data processing was shown impactful enough to yield such enormous fluctuations, we discussed that the experimental apparatus, namely acoustic path an d â€œtrueâ€ ultrasound speed in the sample, could also impact the observed fluctuations as the relative impact of time -of-flight calculation could diminish or potentialize data processing effects. The discussion needs further study as we did not assess the effects of data processing in those other experimental setups. For that, we suggest either the analysis of more samples and in different acoustic cells or conducting simulations, being both works in progress in our research group. We also suggest the charact erization of data processing performance with varied frequencies present in the pulses. Acknowledgements
